trans-unit.source: How to set a static internal private IP
trans-unit.target: How to set a static internal private IP

trans-unit.source: Understanding static internal IPs (DIPs) and how to manage them
trans-unit.target: Understanding static internal IPs (DIPs) and how to manage them

trans-unit.source: How to Set a Static Internal Private IP
trans-unit.target: How to Set a Static Internal Private IP

trans-unit.source: In most cases, you won’t need to specify a static internal IP address for your virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: In most cases, you won’t need to specify a static internal IP address for your virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: VMs in a virtual network will automatically receive an internal IP address from a range that you specify.
trans-unit.target: VMs in a virtual network will automatically receive an internal IP address from a range that you specify.

trans-unit.source: But in certain cases, specifying a static IP address for a particular VM makes sense.
trans-unit.target: But in certain cases, specifying a static IP address for a particular VM makes sense.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your VM is going to run DNS or will be a domain controller.
trans-unit.target: For example, if your VM is going to run DNS or will be a domain controller.

trans-unit.source: A static internal IP address stays with the VM even through a stop/deprovision state.
trans-unit.target: A static internal IP address stays with the VM even through a stop/deprovision state.

trans-unit.source: How to verify if a specific IP address is available
trans-unit.target: How to verify if a specific IP address is available

trans-unit.source: To verify if the IP address 10.0.0.7 is available in a vnet named TestVnet, run the following PowerShell command and verify the value for IsAvailable:
trans-unit.target: To verify if the IP address 10.0.0.7 is available in a vnet named TestVnet, run the following PowerShell command and verify the value for IsAvailable:

trans-unit.source: If you want to test the command above in a safe environment follow the guidelines in Create a Virtual Network to create a vnet named TestVnet and ensure it uses the 10.0.0.0/8 address space.
trans-unit.target: If you want to test the command above in a safe environment follow the guidelines in Create a Virtual Network to create a vnet named TestVnet and ensure it uses the 10.0.0.0/8 address space.

trans-unit.source: How to specify a static internal IP when creating a VM
trans-unit.target: How to specify a static internal IP when creating a VM

trans-unit.source: The PowerShell script below creates a new cloud service named TestService, then retrieves an image from Azure, then creates a VM named TestVM in the new cloud service using the retrieved image, sets the VM to be in a subnet named Subnet-1, and sets 10.0.0.7 as a static internal IP for the VM:
trans-unit.target: The PowerShell script below creates a new cloud service named TestService, then retrieves an image from Azure, then creates a VM named TestVM in the new cloud service using the retrieved image, sets the VM to be in a subnet named Subnet-1, and sets 10.0.0.7 as a static internal IP for the VM:

trans-unit.target: How to retrieve static internal IP information for a VM
